abstract.p: Thomas O'Brien letter responds to July 16 article on estate tax, which mistakenly suggested estate tax is somehow unique in constituting 'double taxation'

block.p: Re ''Soaking the Rich Isn't What It Used To Be'' (Week in Review, July 16):

You perpetuate a dangerous myth that the estate tax somehow is unique in constituting ''double taxation.'' In fact, every dollar is taxed an infinite amount of times as it circulates through the economy. I pay payroll and income tax on an earned dollar, sales taxes when I spend it and tax on interest earned when I put it in a savings account. When I buy a compact disc, the store, the manufacturer and the store clerk are all taxed on it.
Re ''Soaking the Rich Isn't What It Used To Be'' (Week in Review, July 16):

You perpetuate a dangerous myth that the estate tax somehow is unique in constituting ''double taxation.'' In fact, every dollar is taxed an infinite amount of times as it circulates through the economy. I pay payroll and income tax on an earned dollar, sales taxes when I spend it and tax on interest earned when I put it in a savings account. When I buy a compact disc, the store, the manufacturer and the store clerk are all taxed on it.

Wealthy people pay zero percent on unrealized capital gains (if they have no need to sell their stock portfolios), and 98 percent of estates pay a zero percent rate, so in most cases the wealthy pay zero percent on their money. In most cases, income that is unearned is taxed at a much lower rate than income that is earned by the sweat of one's brow.
